bestBHT.bht: Determined to discover the circumstances of Peter's escape, Herod Agrippa subjected the guards and those involved to a thorough examination. Incensed and impotent, he ordered the execution of the guards, attempting to create an impression that Peter's escape was due to their negligence. However, divine intervention overruled Herod's plans, as the prayers of the church prevailed, leading to the cessation of the persecution initiated by royal authority. In the end, Herod's futile efforts ended in divine judgment, while Peter's deliverance showcased the power and protection of God.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: either like the keepers of our Lord's sepulchre, had 'shaken and become as dead men' (Matthew 28:4)
or had slept on their watch and been divinely kept from awaking
Albert Barnes: He subjected them to a rigid scrutiny to ascertain the manner of his escape; for it is evident that Herod did not mean to admit the possibility of a miraculous interposition.
The men on guard were undoubtedly put to death; and thus Herod used all his power to create the impression that Peter had escaped by their negligence.

Thus, by the providence of God, this persecution, that had been commenced, not by popular tumult, but by royal authority and power, and that was aimed at the very pillars of the church, ceased. The prayers of the church prevailed; and the monarch was overcome, disappointed, bummed, and, by divine judgment, soon put to death.
Marvin Vincent: Abode (die triben). Originally, to rub away, or consume; hence, of time, to spend.
Philip Schaff: No doubt bitterly disappointed at not being able to comply with the Jewish desire in the matter of putting to death the famous Nazarene leader..."
Herod left his Jewish capital for a short season, as he thought, and went down to Cæsarea..."
Josephus mentions a desire to be present at games to be celebrated in honour of Claudius Cæsar as a reason for this removal of the king to Cæsarea.
Archibald T. Robertson: He examined (ανακρινας). First aorist active participle of ανακρινω, old verb to sift up and down, to question thoroughly, in a forensic sense.
That they should be put to death (απαχθηνα). First aorist passive infinitive (indirect command) of απαγω, old verb to lead away, especially to execution.
Tarried (διετριβεν). Imperfect active. Herod Agrippa made his home in Jerusalem, but he went to Caesarea to the public games in honour of Emperor Claudius.
John Gill: He examined the keepers; of the prison, and those that were upon the watch, whether they had not been accessary to his escape.
And commanded that they should be put to death: or brought forth, not before a judge to be tried and judged, because they had been examined by Herod already.
And he went down from Judea to Caesarea; not Peter, but Herod.
John Wesley: And thus the wicked suffered in the room of the righteous.
And going down from Judea — With shame, for not having brought forth Peter, according to his promise.

bhtAttempts.bht: After the miraculous escape of Peter from prison, Herod Agrippa launched an investigation to determine how it was possible for such an event to occur. He sought to place blame either on those responsible for guarding Peter's cell, implying that they had slept through their duty, or on individuals who may have been part of a conspiracy to aid in Peter's escape. Showing the extent of his rage and frustration, he had the guards executed. In the end, Herod's vindictive plan was foiled by divine intervention, and his persecution against the church was halted. God answered the prayers of the believers, and Herod himself faced a swift judgment as he met his eventual demise, leaving Judea to attend games in Caesarea. Thus, the wicked suffered in place of the righteous, demonstrating the power and protection of God over His people.

Seeking to assign blame for Peter's miraculous escape, Herod Agrippa meticulously examined the guards and those accountable for Peter's imprisonment. In a fit of rage and disappointment, the guards were executed. However, divine intervention thwarted Herod's oppressive plans as prayers of the faithful prevailed, and his persecution was abruptly halted. Ultimately, Herod's authority and power were no match for the sovereignty of God, who swiftly brought judgment upon him. This turn of events highlights how the wicked ultimately suffer in place of the righteous.

Determined to discover the circumstances of Peter's escape, Herod Agrippa subjected the guards and those involved to a thorough examination. Incensed and impotent, he ordered the execution of the guards, attempting to create an impression that Peter's escape was due to their negligence. However, divine intervention overruled Herod's plans, as the prayers of the church prevailed, leading to the cessation of the persecution initiated by royal authority. In the end, Herod's futile efforts ended in divine judgment, while Peter's deliverance showcased the power and protection of God.

After Peter's miraculous escape from prison, Herod Agrippa conducted a meticulous examination of the guards and those responsible for Peter's imprisonment, hoping to shift blame. Frustrated by his failure to capture Peter, he ordered the execution of the guards, showcasing his impotent vengeance. However, Herod's plans were subverted by divine intervention, as the prayers of the church prevailed and his persecution against the church came to an abrupt end. This turn of events reveals the ultimate triumph of God's power over earthly authorities.

In a desperate attempt to unravel the mystery behind Peter's miraculous escape from prison, Herod Agrippa interrogated the guards and others involved, determined to assign blame. Consumed by rage and disappointment, he ordered the execution of the guards, seeking to create an impression of their negligence. However, divine intervention frustrated Herod's vindictive plot, as the heartfelt prayers of the church prevailed. This unexpected turn of events brought a swift end to Herod's persecution, serving as a reminder of the power and sovereignty of God over earthly powers.
